document.text: Woodrow Wilson Fleshman, 62, of Rt. 1, Appomattox died at 1210 a.m. on Tuesday, Novem ber 23, 1976 at the Virginia Baptist Hospital. He was the husband of Mrs. Agnes Ranson Fleshman. Born in Charlotte County, he was the son of the late Samuel Crother Fleshman and Mary Virginia Rogers Fleshman. He was a retired merchant, a former school bus driver for the Appomattox County School System for 20 years, and a member of Rocks Baptist Church. In addition to his wife, he is survived by three sons, Wilson K. Fleshman, W. Rayford Fleshman, Gary R. Fleshman, all of Appomattox two daughters, Mrs. Irma F. Phelps, Miss Debra A. Flesh man both of Appomattox two brothers, George Fleshman of Lynchburg, Harpson Fleshman of Phenix two sisters, Mrs. T. C. Woodall of Newport News, Mrs. Edward Joy of Richmond, and three grandchildren. Km ineral services will be lBqpucted at 200 P.M. pn Thursday at Rocks Baptist. Church with burial in the church cemetery. The family will be at Robinson Funeral Home from 700 until 900 p.m. on Wednesday.

document.text: Woodmen of the World Camp 71 in Appomattox will conduct their annual Radio Day Oct. 1. ...... This community project is made, possible through the cooperation of local radio station WTTX-FM 107. Local Woodmen will man the radio station the entire day. Proceeds from the project will assist the many community projects that are being supported by the Fraternal ism of Woodcraft such as local fine and rescue units, Dixie Youth Association activities, the Special Olympics, churches and civie organizations placement of Christian and American flags, special benefit drives, crutches, walkers, and wheelchairs for the disabled, and other projects. During the coming days, local Woodsmen will contact local citizens and businesses in order to give them the opportunity to be a part of this annuiiovent. If you desire to take part in the activity and are not contacted, the committee apologizes and ask that you get in touch with Chairman, Steve Marshall at 352-5790 or Co-chairman Floyd Fleshman at 352-8049. document.text: Woodman of the World Camp 71 and Woodman of the World Grove 6083 have recently made a big donation to the Appomattox County Rescue Squad. This fine organization has donated funds to purchase a LIFEPAK 5 heart monitor and the Via Phone box that is used with this equipment to transm it cardiograms to the coronary care unit at a hospital in Lynchburg. In the above photo, R. B. Moore far right is shown presenting check for the 3500 equipm ent to Ray Noble, Training Officer of the Appo mattox County Rescue Squad. Other members qf thq, WOW organization shown in photo are, left to right, Cecil Deaner, Floyd Fleshman, and Steve Marshall. Fourth from the left is Jimmy Rogers, Captain of the Rescue Squad, holding the Via Phone box and next to him is Pete Doss, Rescue Squads 1st Lieutenant, holding the Lifepak 5 monitor. Mrs. Margie Doss Rieder is president of the WOW Grove 6073 and Mr. Harry Ranson is president of the WOW Camp 71. With this donation from thé Woodmen of the World, the Appomattox County Rescue Squad now has two emergency vehicles with the equipment necessary to monitor patients while en route to a hospital.

document.text: winner. An additional prize will be awarded for the closest to the hole on No. 3 and the longest drive on No. 4. Present U. S. G. A. rules will govern play except as amended by local club rules. Scorers are not required, however, all play ers in each foursome shall at test the scores by signing the score card before turning it in at the starters tent. Winter rules shall apply which permits improving lies in the fairways only approx. 12 in. and not in any rough or hazard. Out of Bounds areas are identified with the white markers and the la goon on hole No. 9. Since the course will be closed to normal play at 1100 a.m. these three 3 days, all members are urged to come out and participate, helping to make this a Super Tournament . In order that tournament play is not delayed, all participants must be on their assigned start ing tees no later than 1225 p.m. on all three 3 days and every one is asked not to practice on the greens prior to play thus reserving the best possible con ditions for actual play. If ad ditional information is needed, please contact your tournament committee H. W. Conner, G.H. Jamerson, Tony Gutherie or Floyd Fleshman, Jr. In case of rain, the tourna ment will be played the follow ing weekend, Sept. 11  12 and it will consist of 36 holes in stead of 54, with flights deter mined after the first 18 holes are completed.

document.text: William H. Seawell, Director of Instruction, Mecklenburg County Public Schools, will be the guest speaker at the Robert E. Lee Chap ter Father and Son Banquet here Friday night. The annual banquet will be held in the cafeteria of the Appomattox Elementary School, at 700 P. M. Ralph Reynolds, Chapter Presi dent, will serve as master of cere monies, with Fred Caldwell, Chap ter Sentinel, giving the official wel come to fathers and guests. Wesley Newcomb, Chapiter Vice-President, will introduce the guests, and Frank Inge, Chapter Treasurer, will tell seme of the highlights of the F. F. A. program during the past year. Bobby Barger, Chapter Reporter, will provide entertainment. Floyd Fleshman, Jr. will introduce the guest speaker. This banquet is an annual affair with the local chapter, in which they give recognition to and experience a fellowship with their parents, who play a large part in determining how successful their work in voca tional agriculture and the F. F. A. will be. The Appomattox Garden Club ladies are serving the banquet this year. The menu will be fruit cock tail, ham, mashed potatoes, lima beans, celery, pickles, rolls, coffee or milk, and pie and ice cream.

document.text: We would like to thank everyone who came out on Saturday night to support the program sponsored by Miss Celia Mosley for the NAACP. The Star liners of Rustburg presented a lovely musical program. Everyone present also enjoy ed the program presented on Sunday night by the Holiness Singers and the Gospel Quintette for the benefit of the youth club. The program that was scheduled for Sunday night has been postponed until a later date. Beginning Wednesday, Oct. 20, there will be a series of services at the Jordan Baptist Church. Our guest for the week will be Wed - Rev.W. R. Jones  1st Baptist South Lynchburg Thursday - Rev. Roy Wood and Morning Star Friday - Rev. J. W. Paige and his mens chorus Saturday - Rev. C. W. Dunning and the Mt. Carmel Young Adult Choir. These services will begin at 745 p.m. each night with prayer service and preaching will be at 800. On Sunday Oct. 24, this series of services wfll come to a close at 300 p.m. Rev. Don Lewis and the St. John Gospel Chorus will be our guest. This will also be the close of our state rally. We urge our many friends to join us in these services. Rev. R. McCray will be our guest minister on the 4th Sunday morning at 1100 a.m. as Rev. Elliott is on vacation this month. On the 5th Sunday, October 31st, at 600 p.m. the Harps of Lion wfll celebrate their 5th anniversary at the Jordan Baptist Church. Many of your favorite groups will appear on the program, so plan now to attend. We are glad to report Mrs. Dorothy Fleshman is out and getting around after her stay in the hospital.

document.text: We tirialiy played with some intensity, and we had some of the kids who have Itcen hurt back playing, again. Justus said of life game. At last, we were both mentally and physically,  prepared for a game. Justus noted that the Raiders comeback actually started in last weeks game , against Radford, which the Appomattox team lost. The kids were starting to get fired up against Radford, and this week they carried it out, Justus said. J ustus cited the efforts of Fleshman. who carried the ball 16 times for 102 yards, as well as Rodney Bryant, who picked up 37 yards oq 11 runs. Quarterback Ron Carter and the entire offensive line also deceived the coachs praise for their performance Friday night. Reflecting on the season, Justus said he is very pleased overall, considering all things. He noted that the many injuries which key players suffered throughout the year served to show the  coaching staff some younger talent which may have been overlooked had the starters not been hurt. I was very impressed with the younger players, as well as with the older bids, Justus said. Its always nice to end the season on a winning note, and right now, were starting to think about getting ready for next year.

document.text: We publish an interview with Mr. Fleshman on this subject in another column and ask that the people be left to decide whether or not be intended becoming a candidate. Again where is the milk in this coooanutP Mr. Fleshman claims he conld have received the endorse ment of both the Republican and Popnlist partita, but he would not make the raceholding in his pocket the certificate, he suddenly throws up the sponge and leaves the field, realizing no doubt that it is better now than the returns would show, laving made the fight for offloe before, and going down under heavy majorities, we do not doubt our friends wisdom in making the wise decision he did. WM. DANIIL HIX. This candidate, who paraded his democracy before the people of this connty during the canvass for the primary nomination is the latest surprise the people have. Having submitted his claims to the primary and there suffering defeat he now has the egotism to come forth as an udependent Independent what Republican ? Surely there is not a democrat in the whole county who will now tnrn his back on the nom inee of his party and violate the ledge made in said primary to sup- ort its nominee. How any self- respecting man can violate snob a pledge is more than we can under stand. When Mr. Hix submitted iis claims to the primary he with every other honorable Democrat be came bound by its result. Had Mr, Hix received the nomination of that primary it would have been a pleas nre for all Democrats to have unite and given him their support, and he wonld have found us with all of Mr. Ligons friends fighting his battle as oar party nominee. Now the duty of every Democrat and every man who voted in that primary is plain. Theres no earthly excase for Hixs candidacy. He had his chance. He,lost. He now seeks office at the hands of those he de nounced. Republicans. The Re publicans will not support him ant the Democrats will oppose him, anc altogether Mr. Hix seems to have placed himself in a position from which it is useless for his friends to attempt his reformation. Democrats your duty is plain anc that yonr rebuke to bolters will severe no sane man doubts. Mr. Ligon, the Democratic nom inee is making a good canvass, spoke at Campbell court Monday, and that connty as well as Appo mattox will administer to Mr. Hix the greatest and, most crashing defeat of his life. Democrats the election is less than three weeks offtake nothing for granted, but go earnestly to work to give our nominee such a majority as will forever settle the indepen dents in this county. Make the vic tory a glorious one, the defeat cer tain. Work!

document.text: We, have a young dub, in terms of experience, but they are a hard-working group. This is how Appomattox varsity basketball coach Coty Dickerson describes this sea sons Raider team. The Raiders, who were scheduled to play Gretna yesterday Tuesday after the Tin-Virginian deadline, have two returning starters from last years team. Jeff Miller, at center, and Rick Caldwell at guard are returning starters from last years, team. Kevin Ferguson, who is currently recuperating from a knee injury sustained during football season, is a third Raider who started on last years basketball squad. How-  ever, it is uncertain when, if at all during this season, Ferguson will be able to play basketball. Norman Turner  and Fton Carter were scheduled to start Tuesday evening at the forward positions, according to Coach Dickerson. Kim Humb les, who did not play on last years team, will start at the other guard position. Jody Williams and Richie Guill are two other guards who will likely see a lot of action this year. Players who moved up from last years junior varsity squad this year  include Derwin Harvey, a forward Dennis Fleshman, who plays both guard qnd forward Tim Bennett, a guard and Bobby Carter, a center. In addition to returnees from last years team and players up from last years junior varsity, Dickerson has two newcomers on this years squad, forward Greg Mayberry, and Miark Kelso, a guard. I think weve made some strides, Dickerson says in reference to his teams pre- season performance and pro gress. All-Region ID

document.text: We had our 4-H Club meeting Wednesday November 14. Our president called the meeting to order. Connie Woodson and Sheerie Coving ton led us in the pledge to the American Flag and 4-H Flag. Then the song leaders, Mike Powell and Vanessa Smith led us in songs and games. Then the secretary Kathy Johnson read the minutes of the last meeting. Then our president turned the meeting over the Mr. Sweet. Mr. Sweet had a game for the class to play. The game was called PETS. We also talked about forestry and seeding which we will talk about next month. After we finished the game, Mr. Sweet passed out answer sheets from the game PETS. Reporter, Willis Fleshman

document.text: We extend many thanks to the Appomattox Area 4-Ifers for the work which they put into the Walkathon and also to the many other people assisting with the event. Over 200 young people walked with only fifteen not completing the 10 mile route. A total of over 4,000 was pledged to the people walking. We realize that though the walk is finished some of the most important work - collecting pledges - remains to be done. We urge all of you who walked to collect your pledges and to turn them in as soon as possible. Pledge money may be turned in at the Appomattox County Extension Office, Appomattox Element ary School, Appomattox Ele mentary School, Appomattox Middle School, Pamplin Ele na entary and in the MD box in the office of Appomattox High School. We were happy to have Mr. Norman King, Richmond area Director for the Muscular Dystrophy Association, taking part in the walk. Mr. King completed the entire walk. Once all the pledges have been collected we will announce the winner of the bicycle which will be awarded to the person turning in the most pledge money. Were sorry that we didnt have pictures of the walkathon in progress. Howev er, we did get several right after the walkathon of some of the 200 people that walked. All funds raised in the Walkathon will be given to the Muscular Dystrophy Associa tion to provide for research and service programs provided by the Association. Again, many thanks are extended to the I people walking in the eqent, th o s e a s s is tin g w ith th e Walkathon and those of -you who pledged money to the walkers. We also wish to especially thank the Pepsi Cola Company from Lynchburg, Virginia for providing a concession stand of Pepsis and Dr. Peppers for the walkers at the end of the route. We appreciate their coopera tion and help with this worthy cause. Note also goes to Kings Markets for providing all ice used in providing the refresh ment stands along the route. We hope that we will patronize these sponsors for their help and assistance in this communi ty service project. The following persons walk ed in the 4-H Muscular Dystrophy Walkathon Carroll Almond, Jerome Bell, Percy Bell, Duane Blanks, John Randal Caldwell, Tommy Campbell, E. J. document.text: VIRGINIA IN THE CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE COUNTY OF APPOMATTOX ROBERT H, GRAY, JR ., Committee for Alberta Flesh- man V. ALBERTA FLESHMAN, a person under disability and All heirs of distributees of Alberta Fleshman and others, being designated PARTIES UNKNOWN ORDER OF PUBLICATION The object of this suit is to sell the read property of Alberta Fleshman consisting of .48 acres, more or less, located in the Southside Magisterial Dis tric t, Appom attox County, Virginia said Alberta Flesh man being a person under disability. _ And an Affidavit having been made and filed that there are or may be persons, whose names and locations are unknown, who would be heirs or distributees of Alberta Fleshman, were she deceased, and further being .made parties defendant by the general description of PAR TIES UNKNOWN. It is ORDERED that the heirs or distributees of Alberta Fleshman,were she deceased, being designated PARTIES UNKNOWN, appear before this Court to do what is necessary to nrotect their interest on or before the 5th day of January, 1982. It is further ORDERED that the foregoing portion of this Order be published once a week for four 4 successive weeks in The Times-Virginian, Appomat tox, Virginia. BARBARA ft. WILLIAMS,  Clerk  Robert H. Gray,- Jr. P.O. Box 777 Appomattox, Virginia 24522 80ll-18-4te
